titleInfo.title: Actas de las Jornadas Borges y el Uruguay

originInfo.publisher: Departamento de Literaturas Uruguaya y Latinoamericana
Facultad de Humanidades y Ciencias de la Educación, Universidad de la República

mods.note: edición a cargo de Sylvia Lago y Alicia Torres.

"Durante los días 26 y 27 de agosto de 1999 y en el marco de los festejos por los 150 años de la instalación de la Universidad de la República, se realizaron en la Facultad de Humanidades y Ciencias de la Educación las Jornadas "Borges y el Uruguay" organizadas por el Departmento de Literaturas Uruguaya y Latinoamericana."--Intro.

mods.abstract: This volume reconsiders the work and cultural import of Adolfo Bioy Casares (1914-1999), who is best known for his collaborations with Jorge Luis Borges.
mods.tableOfContents: Intro -- Series Editors' Foreword -- Acknowledgements -- List of figures -- Note on translations -- Notes on contributors -- Introduction: Rethinking Adolfo Bioy Casares -- Adolfo Bioy Casares: a biographical sketch -- Borges's appendix: reflections on Bioy's diary -- Bioy and Borges: from the third man to the worldof Bustos Domecq -- Every man is an island: Bioy's fiction -- 1969: youth and rebellion in Diario de la guerra del cerdoand Invasión -- The fantastic in Bioy's short stories -- Bioy, Ocampo and the photographic image -- To love in the infinitive: time, image and the powers of thefalse in La invención de Morel -- Index.

Yates -- Estructura oximorónica en los ensayos de Borges / Jaime Alazraki -- Sueño, memoria, producción del significante en "Ficciones" de Jorge Luis Borges / Gerardo Mario Goloboff --Del anacronismo al simulacro / Saúl Yurkievich -- La obra visible de Macedonio Fernández / John C. Murchison -- Trabajando con Borges / Norman Thomas di Giovanni -- Crónica, y reivindicación de Borges / José Luis Giménez-Frontín -- Poemas de Homenaje / Jorge Guillén -- Borges en Oklahoma 1969 / Ivar Ivask -- De la literatura, o un viaje imaginario con Jorge Luis Borges / Jorge Semprún.
mods.note: Translation of: The cardinal points of Borges. Spanish edition contains additional essays.
Some of the articles were presented at the International Symposium on Borges, held at the University of Oklahoma, Dec. 5-6, 1969, and were first published in the summer 1971 issue of Books abroad.

titleInfo.title: Being in common
titleInfo.subTitle: nation, subject, and community in Latin American literature and culture

mods.abstract: "Being in Common analyzes key works of twentieth-century Latin American literature and culture as precursors of contemporary theories of globalization. Silvia Rosman studies how texts from the 1940s and '50s by major Latin American authors, such as Alejo Carpentier, Ezequiel Martinez Estrada, Octavio Paz, and Jorge Luis Borges, provide alternatives to traditional forms of national, linguistic, or geographical belonging and thus allow us to think the commonality of experience differently. These texts offer articulations of community that challenge the totalizing and often violent homogeneity of identity or difference, the priority of the Subject and the location of culture. Rosman persuasively demonstrates how they explore ways of being in common - the communal relation - when the notion of a common being - a totalized conception of community - is shown to be untenable. In doing so she incorporates and looks beyond her predecessors theoretical resources to urgent contemporary preoccupations with how to imagine identity in a "post-national" moment."--BOOK JACKET.
mods.tableOfContents: Introduction: The Interrupted Quest: Rethinking Nation, Subject, and Community in Latin American Literature and Culture -- 1. Writing Place Names: Travel and Theory in Alejo Carpentier's Los pasos perdidos -- 2. Image, History, Tradition: Ezequiel Martinez Estrada's Alter-Nations -- 3. On Being Mexican, for Example: Octavio Paz and the Dialectics of Universality -- 4. Borges: On Reading, Translation, and the Impossibility of Naming.

subject.topic: National characteristics, Latin American, in literature

titleInfo.subTitle: Borges, Gerchunoff, and Argentine-Jewish writing
